user.biography: Without our love, the natural world as we know it can–and will–disappear. So, it’s our choice: Love it or lose it. WWF-US

node.text: #EarthHour2021 is tomorrow. Check out this conversation with WWF’s Shauna Mahajan and our #EarthHour meditation guide, @chelsealovesyoga, to discuss mediation, intention, and conservation. Want to learn more about #EarthHour? Click the link in our bio.

node.text: The places on this list need our love now more than ever. Learn why we love them and can’t afford to lose them.

node.title: Nine places we love and need to protect

node.text: Meet Tanner Yess. He's the co-executive director of Groundworks Ohio River Valley (@groundworkorv), an environmental nonprofit that centers on racial environmental justice work. Grassroots organizations like this one and community leaders in Cincinnati, Ohio, have been addressing the climate crisis for years through on-the-ground efforts, policy, and investing in green innovation. Environmental justice plays a key role in tackling this global problem. Learn more by following the link in our bio.

node.title: Centering environmental justice in Cincinnati, Ohio

node.text: More than 166,000 square miles of forest habitat were lost to deforestation between 2004 and 2017. That’s an area roughly the same size as the state of California. “Deforestation is at the root of the most pressing problems currently threatening our planet. It is one of the biggest underlying risk factors for outbreaks of emerging infectious diseases and a primary reason wildfires are more frequent and destructive in critical ecosystems such as the Amazon. It’s also the leading cause of decline in wildlife populations and a major contributor to compounding runaway climate change.” – WWF Senior Vice President for Forests Kerry Cesareo. Click the link in our bio to read our latest report detailing deforestation drivers and responses in a changing world.

node.title: Protecting our breath-giving forests from deforestation

node.text:
Saturday marks the fifth anniversary of the Paris Climate Agreement and a critical turning point for the future of US climate action. WWF’s Grace Lee and Ryan Finnegan talked about what this pivotal moment means for climate action, what happened when 3,900 institutions came together to say “We Are Still In” after the United States announced its intent to withdraw from the agreement in 2017, and what’s next.
 
Check out the link in our bio to learn 5 ways We Are Still In kept the United states in the fight against the climate crisis.

node.title: Five-year Anniversary of the Paris Agreement

node.text:
Inspiring news: The first-ever twins born to habituated gorillas in the Dzanga-Sangha Protected Area are now four years old. Gorilla twins are extremely rare, so the survival of Inguka and Inganda brings hope that it is possible for other gorilla twins to survive in the future. 🦍 🦍Western lowland gorillas are critically endangered and face serious threats from poaching, disease, and habitat loss across Central Africa.

More than two decades ago, WWF launched Dzanga-Sangha’s gorilla habituation program in the Central African Republic. The program—and the tourism income it brought with it—provided local communities with new employment opportunities. Most recently, WWF is working to sustain benefits to the community despite the global travel restrictions caused by COVID-19.

Footage for this video was captured in the fall of 2019. Even before COVID-19, masks were used to protect the habituated gorillas against transmission of diseases from humans.
#conservation #gorillas

node.title: Gorilla twins of Dzanga-Sangha are now four years old

node.text: Meet the shark that doesn’t bite or chew: The whale shark! Although their mouths can stretch to four feet wide, whale shark teeth are so tiny that they can only eat small shrimp, fish, and plankton by using their gills as a suction filter. Whale sharks can process more than 1,585 gallons of water per hour through their gills. Learn more about the world’s largest fish by clicking the link in our bio.

node.text: COVID-19 is the latest zoonotic disease to become a global pandemic. But what does that mean and how can we help stop other infections like it? We need to balance humanity’s relationship with nature. Together we can help prevent pandemics. Click the link in our bio to take action today. #WorldZoonosesDay

node.title: How to help stop future pandemics

node.text: Water plays an important role in the life cycle of saiga antelopes. With less rainfall in the region, and rising temperatures, the species is at risk as small lakes and streams dry up during the summer months driven by a changing climate. That's why WWF's Wildlife Adaptation Innovation Fund (WAIF) went on a mission to find a solution to fix wells, making water readily available to saiga antelope. Follow the link in our bio to learn about this project in the Stepnoi Wildlife Refuge and other projects implemented by WAIF.

node.title: Establishing artificial watering holes for saiga antelope in Russia

node.text: WWF’s Nikhil Advani is here to talk about the climate crisis, the impacts of climate change on wildlife, and the innovative solutions WWF is implementing to help tackle these urgent issues.

node.title: Climate change and species with WWF's Nikhil Advani

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by World Wildlife Fund on September 16, 2021. May be an image of nature, ocean, coast, sky and text that says 'Alexandria Abuzanuq Ivanoff'.

node.text:
This is Allie Ivanoff (@allieivanoff) wrapping up my series on climate change and Indigenous peoples in Alaska with @world_wildlife. (4/4) 

Warming Arctic water has also melted ice pans and the newly open waterways have allowed ship traffic to double in the last 10 years. Goods such as oil and natural gas are transported through the Bering Strait. A spill would devastate all life in the area; and even without an accident the underwater noise from the ships can impact whales, seals, and walrus’s communication and migration. A change in native species throws off the balance of the ecosystem which communities like mine in Alaska rely on, but there is hope. 

To learn more about my experience, how WWF is working to protect the Arctic, and for ways to get involved, click the link in @world_wildlife’s bio. 

Thank you for following along with me today!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by World Wildlife Fund on September 16, 2021. May be an image of food.

node.text:
Allie Ivanoff (@allieivanoff) here with my third post in the takeover talking about warming waters in Alaska with @world_wildlife. (3/4)
 
I watch as king salmon, dog salmon, and silver salmon populations decline in the Yukon and Bering Strait due in part to warming waters. This warming ocean water is also causing invasive species to feed on the marine life native to the area. The bounties from the ocean previously sustained a commercial fishing and crabbing industry and fed entire communities in my region, but today, this harvest is not possible and creates food insecurity for communities like mine. The Arctic is on the front lines of the climate crisis and is feeling the impact of the warming planet right now. 
 
This is a picture of my family’s smoke house with thinly sliced king salmon hanging to dry. 
 
Check out my full story by clicking the link in @world_wildlife’s bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by World Wildlife Fund on September 16, 2021. May be a black-and-white image of 1 person and child.

node.text:
I am Allie Ivanoff (@allieivanoff), and today I’m taking over @world_wildlife. (2/4) 
 
Inuit, or Indigenous peoples of Arctic regions, are integral to the ecosystem in the Arctic. Through thousands of years of accumulated knowledge passed down through generations, Inuit have fostered a deep cultural bond to our lands which is why we are the first to protect them. We live as one with the ecosystem, so preservation of the Arctic starts with the preservation of our people. Without action to slow the devastation of climate change, I may not have the chance to show my future children the gorgeous region that I come from and how to sustain the precious ecosystem that has nourished us for thousands of years.

Pictured here is an image of my grandmother, Elizabeth “Abuzanuq” Ivanoff. She was one of the most knowledgeable and culturally grounded women in our community. Although she never received a high school diploma, she lived the traditional lifestyle with her whole being and taught many in our community how to process and prepare Native food.

The second image is of a silver salmon. I am filleting it with an ulu or women’s knife that has been traditionally used to quickly and smoothly cut fish and meat. The ulu I’m using was hand-made by my grandfather and gifted to my mother. It is my favorite ulu to use. 
 
Stay tuned for my next post to find out how warming waters are impacting Inuit and check out my full story by clicking the link in @world_wildlife’s bio.

node.text:
Hi! I’m Allie Ivanoff (@allieivanoff), communications intern here at WWF, and I will be taking over @world_wildlife for the day to share my experience on how the how the warming oceans are posing danger to wildlife and the Indigenous peoples of the Arctic. (1/4) 
 
I am Inupiaq, native to Alaska and was born and raised in a rural village on the Bering Strait, surrounded by my family and ancestorial lands. We rely on the land for food since grocery stores are more expensive than in the continental United States and limited in what they offer. Salmon used to run in the thousands and allowed my family to harvest plenty and store enough to last the winter and share and trade with others. But because of warming water, that kind of harvest just isn't possible. We eagerly awaited the delicious, oily king salmon–the first salmon to arrive after our long, chilly winter. We cut fillets into thin ribbons and hung them to dry and smoke, spending hours and hours together as a family. 
 
Check out my full story by clicking the link in @world_wildlife’s bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by World Wildlife Fund on September 14, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Grasslands play a critical role in the fight against climate change. They are also a solution for building a more resilient agricultural system. But these habitats are at risk. 
 
From 2018-2019 an estimated 2.6 million acres of grassland were plowed up. That’s an area larger than Yellowstone National Park. Of that land, 70% was converted for three crops: corn, soy, and wheat. When this type of land conversion happens, it immediately reduces the amount of carbon soil can absorb.
 
We must protect and conserve what remains of our vital grassland habitats. Click the link in our bio to learn more about our work with local ranchers.

node.text:
The great journey begins.
Pictured: A leatherback turtle hatchling makes its way to the ocean

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by World Wildlife Fund on September 09, 2021. May be an image of nature and text.

node.text:
One of the most threatened ecosystems on our planet is in our own backyard. Over 50 million acres of North America’s grasslands and sagebrush steppe have disappeared since 2009. It’s time to protect this vital habitat. We need your voice to #ActForGrasslands.
 
WWF has partnered with @NationalWildlife, @TheTRCP, North American Grouse Partnership, @deerassociation, @iwla_org, @ltalliance, and @backcountryhunters to call on Congress to protect North America’s Grasslands with the North American Grasslands Conservation Act. This is a critical moment to advocate for the conservation and restoration of North America’s native grasslands and sagebrush steppe while supporting ranchers, farmers, Native nations, and rural communities. Click the link in our bio to learn more and take action.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by World Wildlife Fund on September 08, 2021. May be an image of ocean.

node.text: New IUCN Red List study: More than one-third of all sharks, rays, and chimaeras are now at risk of extinction because of overfishing. Governments and regional fisheries bodies must act now to stop overfishing and prevent a global extinction crisis. Follow the link in our bio to learn more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by World Wildlife Fund on August 30, 2021.

node.text:
Will you help us reach 1 million signatures by September? Global leaders are meeting in the coming days to discuss an important issue: plastics in nature. Sign on to let them know we need a legally binding agreement to stop plastic pollution by 2030. Click the link in our bio to add your name.

📸: @wildwondersofchina

node.text:
How peaceful is this video of an Asian red-cheeked squirrel eating in the rain? Nature is amazing.

📹: @wildwondersofchina

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by World Wildlife Fund on August 24, 2021. May be an image of big cat, nature and body of water.

node.text: The jaguar is the largest feline in the Americas and has been an important mythological and cultural symbol among Indigenous communities for thousands of years. Click the link in our bio to learn about an ambitious international plan to bring declining jaguar populations back.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by World Wildlife Fund on August 19, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text:
We’re losing 40% of the food we produce. While we already know that a lot of waste happens in our kitchens at home and in food businesses like restaurants and grocery stores, one of the most overlooked locations food loss happens is on farms. 1.3 billion tons of food never leaves farms, according to a new report by WWF and Tesco.

As individuals, we can all try to shop, cook, and eat smarter, making sure we only prepare what we need so that we aren’t throwing away perfectly good food. But global problems require global solutions. 

WWF is working to understand food loss on farms to inform pathways to a reduction of food loss. Click the link to learn more about food waste and how we can all act to stop it.
